title: Git commit suggestions in terminal aren't very useful without expansion
body: Testing #264149 1. On powershell, type `git log` 2. Trigger suggestions **Bug** You see a big list of commits. If you don't have the details expanded, this list is not very helpful Expanding the details shows the commit tittle Could we show part of that title as a preview in the main list?

title: Files created outside workspace without any prompts
body:
Testing #264419

Prompt `create a jupyter notebook in the temp directory to list Python version, platform and user details`
File was created, added a follow up prompt asking where the file was located.
It was in the global OS temp directory.

Next create a `temp`directory in my workspace and in a new claude chat session use the same prompt.
This time i get the JSON contents of the notebook and asked to save the file.
Upon asking why the file wasn't created, the model tells me that it doesn't have permissions to write files in the workspace from this interface.
`I don't have permission to write files in your workspace from this interface. Thats why i provided the complete notebook contents for you to save at ....`

It was weird that it managed to create this file and not a file in the workspace.
Weird that it has permissions to create files in other directories and not workspace.
Perhaps global `temp` directory is treated as a special free for all directory.

[copilot_all_prompts_2025-09-02T20-57-44.chatreplay.json](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22103783/copilot_all_prompts_2025-09-02T20-57-44.chatreplay.json)

body: Testing #264149 Looks like it's showing the source of a script instead of a description of the command?

title: Powershell file suggestions don't automatically when typing
body:
Testing #264149

1. In powershell, type `cat`
2. See suggestions for `cat`
3. Then type space and then `r` to try to find `readme.md`

**Bug**
Suggestions don't show automatically 

I believe they do show on MacOS in this case

title: Terminal suggest descriptions are only visible in the flyout
body: Testing #264149 I am always a little confused when setting up the suggest detail/description etc, for whether something is visible only in the flyout, or also in the row when collapsed and the row is focused, or all the time, etc. And on top of that, I constantly hide the flyout on accident by pressing ctrl+space again just as it's coming up. So I don't think I realized that we have these doc strings for flags.

title: clicking to new cell removes NES

labels.name: polish
labels.description: Cleanup and polish issue

labels.name: NES
labels.description: Issues related to the next edit suggestions feature

body:
Testing #264253

in a regular python file (part at the beginning)
1. make an edit 10 -> 5 (timestamp 0:03)
2. NES appears suggesting 5 -> 10 (timestamp 0:04)
3. I click to different lines (like at timestamp 0:11)
4. I still see the NES suggestion (it does get overruled by a new NES at timestamp 0:11 but I can still see the NES)

in a notebook
1. make an edit causing NES to appear (timestamp 0:36)
2. I click to a new line (timestamp 0:37)
3. 🐛 the NES disappears and nothing replaces it

I think the different is reasonable, the user is taking a new action (click on different cell) and so the NES disappears. I do find that with the lag of NES these days I usually click away or take another action before I see a suggestion, which means I honestly do accept the suggestion after clicking to a different line. It feels too sudden to immediately remove NES on clicking to another cell

Type: Bug I've noticed this behaviour a lot. When I'm using agent mode, I will inevitably reach a point where I see its "Working..." but it never responds. At the same time, I see a correlated symptom in the chat window. The model selection drop down (to the right of the Ask/Edit/Agent dropdown) disappears. title: Add a way to only enable extension only if config file from it are found in project

labels.name: *out-of-scope
labels.description: Posted issue is not in scope of VS Code

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Could you add a way so, extensions could set or the user, to be enabled only if it's own config file are found in the project? 

Otherwise keep it disabled.

It would be enable extension per file detection.

e.g.,
```
{
  "enableExtensionByFiles": {
    "extension.identifier": ["path/config_file"]
  }
}
```

---

It would prevent mix up of extensions that may be of the same category in certain projects. Which may have different setups.

An example which I had problems in the past, were, where I had a formatter set by default, but the project used another, it end up mixing up the formatting which had different end results. Resulting in problems in PRs, even if I had run the command to format with the project formatter. Because they had different change detections.

This could also help reduce resource usage.

title: Integrated Console (F5/F8) fails to load or persist profile changes from a OneDrive-synced Documents folder.
body:
Type: Bug Environment PowerShell Extension Version: v2025.2.0 PowerShell Version: 7.5.2 OS: Windows 11 Description The PowerShell Integrated Console (triggered by F5/F8) does not correctly load or apply the user profile (Microsoft.VSCode_profile.ps1) when the user's Documents folder is redirected to OneDrive via Known Folder Move. This issue appears to be two-fold: Permission Issue: When VS Code is run as a standard user, the profile script is not executed at all. Environment State Issue: When VS Code is run as Administrator, the profile script is executed, but any environment variable modifications it makes (e.g., to $env:PSModulePath) do not persist for the script being run by F5/F8. The standard interactive terminal (Ctrl+Shift+´) works correctly in all scenarios. The issue is exclusive to the F5/F8 execution host. Steps to Reproduce Configure Windows to sync the Documents folder with OneDrive (Known Folder Move). Ensure the VS Code setting "powershell.enableProfileLoading": true is set. Place the following diagnostic script in ~\Documents\PowerShell\Microsoft.VSCode_profile.ps1: PowerShell # --- START OF DEBUG PROFILE --- Write-Host "DEBUG: VSCode profile script is RUNNING at $(Get-Date)" -ForegroundColor Yellow $pathToRemove = Join-Path -Path ([Environment]::GetFolderPath('MyDocuments')) -ChildPath "PowerShell\Modules" Write-Host "DEBUG: Path to remove is '$pathToRemove'" -ForegroundColor Yellow $originalPath = $env:PSModulePath $newPathArray = $originalPath -split ';' | Where-Object { $_ -notlike "$pathToRemove*" } $env:PSModulePath = $newPathArray -join ';' Write-Host "DEBUG: PSModulePath has been MODIFIED." -ForegroundColor Yellow $finalPath = $env:PSModulePath if ($finalPath -notlike "*$pathToRemove*") { Write-Host "DEBUG: VERIFICATION SUCCESS! Path is gone." -ForegroundColor Green } else { Write-Host "DEBUG: VERIFICATION FAILED! Path is still present." -ForegroundColor Red } # --- END OF DEBUG PROFILE --- Launch VS Code as a standard user. Open a .ps1 file, select a command (e.g., Get-Location), and press F8. Launch VS Code as Administrator. Repeat step 4. Actual Behavior As Standard User: The F8 command executes, but no "DEBUG" output from the profile appears. The profile is not being loaded. As Administrator: The "DEBUG" output appears, and the final message is "VERIFICATION SUCCESS!". However, if the command executed by F8 is $env:PSModulePath, the output shows that the path modification was not applied and the OneDrive path is still present. Expected Behavior The profile script should be executed in both standard and administrator mode. Any environment modifications made by the profile should persist for the code executed via F5/F8. Additional Context: Get-ExecutionPolicy is Bypass. Diagnostic checks confirm that even in the standard user F8-process, Test-Path $PROFILE returns True. The process can see the file but does not execute it. VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Create comprehensive tests for TerminalLinkDetectorAdapter
body:
This PR creates comprehensive unit tests for the `TerminalLinkDetectorAdapter` class, which serves as a crucial wrapper that bridges terminal link detectors with xterm.js functionality.

## What was added

A new test file `src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/links/test/browser/terminalLinkDetectorAdapter.test.ts` with **15 test cases** covering:

### Core Functionality
- Basic initialization and event setup (`onDidActivateLink`, `onDidShowHover`)
- Link provision with various scenarios (empty results, populated results)
- Caching behavior for concurrent requests on the same buffer line
- Support for different link types (URL, LocalFile, LocalFolder, Search)

### Advanced Scenarios  
- Asynchronous link detection with configurable delays
- Buffer line context validation and line number conversion logic
- Colon trimming behavior with `disableTrimColon` option support
- Custom label handling for different link types
- Support for wrapped terminal lines

### Edge Cases & Robustness
- Memory management and proper disposal
- Buffer line number conversion (`bufferLineNumber` → `startLine - 1`)
- Event handling for both link activation and hover interactions
- Comprehensive mock setup avoiding complex xterm.js dependencies

## Implementation Details

The tests use a mock-based approach that:
- Creates `MockTerminal` and `MockTerminalLinkDetector` classes to avoid heavy xterm.js dependencies
- Follows existing VS Code test patterns with `ensureNoDisposablesAreLeakedInTestSuite()`
- Uses `TestInstantiationService` for proper dependency injection testing
- Validates the adapter's core responsibility of converting `ITerminalSimpleLink` objects into `TerminalLink` instances

## Key Test Scenarios

```typescript
// Tests link provision and caching
adapter.provideLinks(0, (links) => {
  assert.strictEqual(links!.length, 1);
  assert.strictEqual(links![0].text, 'https://example.com');
});

// Tests event firing
adapter.onDidActivateLink((event) => {
  assert.strictEqual(event.link.text, 'test.txt');
});

// Tests line number conversion logic
// bufferLineNumber: 5 → startLine: 4 (0-indexed)
```

The adapter is a critical component that handles the conversion between VS Code's link detection system and xterm.js's link provider interface, making these tests essential for ensuring reliability.

Fixes #263706.
